aspace_helpers.title: Generating MARC records from C0140 EAD component records/archival objects in Resource records

comments.body: Going back to the 7xx, can you provide the relator values in ASpace that should trigger the creation of the 7xx please? (Or do you want the 7xx independent of relator, for any role=creator?)
I don't think we are looking to the relator values in this case, but I would like @faithc to confirm.

Regarding whether to have holdings in these records, I would favor having them-- they display the location in a highly visible way, and our collection level records have them, so there would be a level of consistency. There shouldn't be any danger of people requesting these materials through the catalog because, as I understand it, there will be no item records associated with the holdings and the request button will be suppressed.

(After lurking a long time)
Regarding Lynn's comment about holdings: I believe there has to be "inventory" of some kind for a record to display in Blacklight.  In this case the holdings will be kind of fake, but I think it still has to be there.
Yeah, Alma creates a dummy.

bibdata.title: Bibdata: use the cloud instead of a samba share from the worker box

comments.body: we are testing to move from samba to nfs
In order to implement this request approval from @kevinreiss and @escowles . It will be a new field display in the catalog.

The element with div id="view" is always at the bottom of the page. The viewer-container is the id of the iframe viewer container. We are building this element with id='viewer-container' in javascript. When there is a thumbnail with icon content indicating there is a viewer at the bottom of the page this thumbnail is part of an element with href 'viewer-container'. When the user clicks on the thumbnail or content-icon it will navigate them to the viewer-container at the bottom of the page. example of an element is: ```
Go to viewer
 ``` When there is a text-anchor 'Digital content' in the record page with a link having the fragment https://catalog.princeton.edu/catalog/9946018083506421#view this will still navigate the user to the bottom of the page , because the div element with id=view is always at the bottom of the page and exists as a wrapper of the 'viewer-containers'. Unfortunately this cannot happen right now because the catalog domains that are being created through the indexing process are pulling ids from the figgy_ark_cache which is very old and containes voyager ids. This is why currently in Digital Content : the url would be 'https://catalog.princeton.edu/catalog/4601808#view'. When the user clicks on the url it will open a new page because it resolves to the alma id. The figgy_ark_cache cannot be updated because the specific rake task is broken. This is a different ticket and another discussion but all are connected https://github.com/pulibrary/orangelight/issues/3104. @maxkadel I'm looking into this ticket as well as the rest that are connected in [#3104](https://github.com/pulibrary/orangelight/issues/3104)

openpublishing.title: Document relationship between production and staging environments

comments.body:
Upon extensive examination, I've found the following:

* The missing translations for this issue are already in the Japanese language translation maintained by Weblate, but they are not in the code.
* Translations are pulled from files in both the `locales` directory at the root of the application folder, and in the `lib/pkp/locales` directory.
* The "Custom Locale Editor" plugin allows any existing translation to be edited by the user, in the admin interface.  However, the files must already be present on the server, and the translation key must also already be present in one of those files in order for the user to edit it.
* Custom locale information added in the admin interface is stored in the database; there is a "restore defaults" option for locales buried in the website settings under "Hosted Journals/Settings Wizard/Journal Settings/Languages" where you expand the language in question and click "reload defaults."  See attached screenshot (because this was pretty hard to find) 
* Updated locale translations (pulling from the latest Weblate-translated versions by the community) are tracked by PKP in version control in a separate repository from OJS, https://github.com/pkp/pkp-lib.  These contain substantially more locale files than what comes with the OJS tarball typically used for installation.  The `pkp/pkp-lib` repository is tracked as a git submodule within the greater OJS project (https://github.com/pkp/ojs/blob/main/.gitmodules#L2).
* In this case, there were substantially more Japanese language translation files at https://github.com/pkp/pkp-lib/tree/main/locale/ja_JP than in the base installation.  Adding the `manager.po` file explicitly under `lib/pkp/locales/ja_JP` in the staging installation did in fact appear to address the missing translation.  This is obviously not sustainable, however it should be noted that finding a sustainable way to update the locales from `pkp-lib` is likely a reasonable approach to address this.
* For local development, it is recommended that developers clone the OJS repository and initialized submodules to get all of the latest code.  It is unclear to me what the recommended approach is for non-custom installations. 

Illustration referenced above for "restore defaults":
 
![Screen Shot 2022-08-04 at 3 39 26 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7795797/182941057-9531851c-0865-4308-948a-6710bdcd374e.png)

pdc_describe.title: datacite xml format does not utilize the same fields as datacite json format

comments.body: The ruby gem has been updated to accept xml.  The gem will no longer do validation for us with XML as it does for JSON.  They might be open to pushing our validation up into the gem.

I have just tested uploading this test file (as well as downloading this after it was persisted as an `ActiveStorage::Blob`) successfully from my local environment:

![image.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5b5b6aed981c3204c9ed06c8/a19dea8d-3c74-4b44-a96f-3e2ff62d3a6e)

There appear to be problems limiting the file upload size for the `staging` server:

![image.png](https://images.zenhubusercontent.com/5b5b6aed981c3204c9ed06c8/dc634daf-3d6c-4f2b-85c7-6918e660e1b8)

The following error is being logged on the NGINX Plus nodes:

```
2022/08/04 14:55:32 [error] 1972398#1972398: *16920700 client intended to send too large body: 3069284 bytes, client: 172.20.203.68, server: pdc-describe-staging.princeton.edu, request: "POST /describe/works/56/file-upload HTTP/2.0", host: "pdc-describe-staging.princeton.edu", referrer: "https://pdc-describe-staging.princeton.edu/describe/works/56/file-upload"
2022/08/04 14:55:32 [error] 1972398#1972398: *16920700 output on closed stream while sending to client, client: 172.20.203.68, server: pdc-describe-staging.princeton.edu, request: "GET /describe/packs/js/application-261dcf4715ff79a9c038.js HTTP/2.0", upstream: "http://128.112.204.77:80/describe/packs/js/application-261dcf4715ff79a9c038.js", host: "pdc-describe-staging.princeton.edu", referrer: "https://pdc-describe-staging.princeton.edu/describe/works/56/file-upload"
```
https://github.com/pulibrary/princeton_ansible/issues/3197 is necessary to resolve the NGINX Plus errors.
